metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.html:
String indexOf()
String lastIndexOf()
String search()

See Also:

Basic String Methods
String Templates
 String match()
String matchAll()
String includes()
String startsWith()
String endsWith()

content.text: The indexOf() method returns the index (position) of the first occurrence of a string in a string, or it returns -1 if the string is not found:
content.html: The indexOf() method returns the index (position) of the first occurrence of a string in a string, or it returns -1 if the string is not found:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate");

content.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate");

content.code_html:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate");

content.html: JavaScript counts positions from zero.

content.text: 0 is the first position in a string, 1 is the second, 2 is the third, ...
content.html: 0 is the first position in a string, 1 is the second, 2 is the third, ...

content.text: The lastIndexOf() method returns the index of the last occurrence of a specified text in a string:
content.html: The lastIndexOf() method returns the index of the last occurrence of a specified text in a string:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("locate");

content.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("locate");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("locate");

content.code_html:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("locate");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("locate");

content.text: Both indexOf() , and lastIndexOf() return -1 if the text is not found:
content.html: Both indexOf(), and lastIndexOf() return -1 if the text is not found:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("John");

content.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("John");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("John");

content.code_html:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("John");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.lastIndexOf("John");

content.text: Both methods accept a second parameter as the starting position for the search:
content.html: Both methods accept a second parameter as the starting position for the search:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate", 15);

content.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate", 15);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate", 15);

content.code_html:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate", 15);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
let index = text.indexOf("locate", 15);

content.text: The lastIndexOf() methods searches backwards (from the end to the beginning), meaning: if the second parameter is 15 , the search starts at position 15, and searches to the beginning of the string.
content.html: The lastIndexOf() methods searches backwards (from the end to the beginning), meaning: if the second parameter is 15, the search starts at position 15, and searches to the beginning of the string.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.lastIndexOf("locate", 15);

content.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.lastIndexOf("locate", 15);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.lastIndexOf("locate", 15);

content.code_html:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.lastIndexOf("locate", 15);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.lastIndexOf("locate", 15);

content.text: The search() method searches a string for a string (or a regular expression) and returns the position of the match:
content.html: The search() method searches a string for a string (or a regular expression) and returns the position of the match:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search("locate");

content.code:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search("locate");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search("locate");

content.code_html:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search("locate");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!";
text.search("locate");

content.text: The two methods, indexOf() and search() , are equal?
content.html: The two methods, indexOf() and search(), are equal?

content.text: They accept the same arguments (parameters), and return the same value?
content.html: They accept the same arguments (parameters), and return the same value?

content.text: The two methods are NOT equal. These are the differences:
content.html: The two methods are NOT equal. These are the differences:

content.text: You will learn more about regular expressions in a later chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about regular expressions in a later chapter.

content.text: The match() method returns an array containing the results of matching a string against a string (or a regular expression).
content.html: The match() method returns an array containing the results of matching a string against a string (or a regular expression).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match("ain");
"The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"

content.code:
let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain";
text.match("ain");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match("ain");
"The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"

content.code_html:
let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain";
text.match("ain");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"; 
text.match("ain");
"The rain in SPAIN stays mainly in the plain"

content.text: If a regular expression does not include the g modifier (global search), match() will return only the first match in the string.
content.html: If a regular expression does not include the g modifier (global search), match() will return only the first match in the string.

content.text: Read more about regular expressions in the chapter JS RegExp .
content.html: Read more about regular expressions in the chapter JS RegExp.

content.text: The matchAll() method returns an iterator containing the results of matching a string against a string (or a regular expression).
content.html: The matchAll() method returns an iterator containing the results of matching a string against a string (or a regular expression).

content.code_html: const iterator = text.matchAll("Cats");

content.text: If the parameter is a regular expression, the global flag (g) must be set, otherwise a TypeError is thrown.
content.html: If the parameter is a regular expression, the global flag (g) must be set, otherwise a TypeError is thrown.

content.code_html: const iterator = text.matchAll(/Cats/g);

content.text: If you want to search case insensitive, the insensitive flag (i) must be set:
content.html: If you want to search case insensitive, the insensitive flag (i) must be set:

content.code_html: const iterator = text.matchAll(/Cats/gi);

content.html: matchAll() is an ES2020 feature.

content.text: matchAll() does not work in Internet Explorer.
content.html: matchAll() does not work in Internet Explorer.

content.text: The includes() method returns true if a string contains a specified value.
content.html: The includes() method returns true if a string contains a specified value.
Otherwise it returns false.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world");

content.code:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world");

content.code_html:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.includes("world");

content.html: includes() is case sensitive.
includes() is an ES6 feature.

content.text: includes() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: includes() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: The startsWith() method returns true if a string begins with a specified value.
content.html: The startsWith() method returns true if a string begins with a specified value.
Otherwise it returns false:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("Hello");

content.code:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("Hello");

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("Hello");

content.code_html:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("Hello");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("Hello");

content.text: A start position for the search can be specified:
content.html: A start position for the search can be specified:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 5)

content.code:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 5)

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 5)

content.code_html:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 5)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text = "Hello world, welcome to the universe.";
text.startsWith("world", 5)

content.html: startsWith() is case sensitive.
startsWith() is an ES6 feature.

content.text: startsWith() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: startsWith() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: The endsWith() method returns true if a string ends with a specified value.
content.html: The endsWith() method returns true if a string ends with a specified value.
Otherwise it returns false:

content.code_html:
let text = "John Doe";
text.endsWith("Doe");

content.html: endsWith() is case sensitive.
endsWith() is an ES6 feature.

content.text: endsWith() is not supported in Internet Explorer.
content.html: endsWith() is not supported in Internet Explorer.

content.text: For a complete String reference, go to our:
content.html: For a complete String reference, go to our:
Complete JavaScript String Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all string properties and methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all string properties and methods.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let x = 'Hello world!'; alert(x.indexOf('Hello')); What will be the alerted result?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let x = 'Hello world!';
alert(x.indexOf('Hello'));
What will be the alerted result?
